awd_titl_txt: A Workshop to Enhance America's Research Translation for Prosperity and Social Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
This project funds a workshop to explore strategies for accelerating and increasing the capacity for translational research within a wide range of higher education institutions. A few universities are performing well, with well-established and effective tech transfer offices, offering strong incentives for research translation, engaged faculty, and munificent entrepreneurial support services. Many institutions with high potential currently underperform. Many of these institutions are minority-serving, located in geographically remote or sparse entrepreneurial ecosystems. These institutions are often under-resourced, lacking internal support for translational activities, and without incentives to promote technology transfer or value creation to their faculty.  The objective of this workshop is to discuss strategies to increase the translation of research outputs and increase the benefits to constituents and communities. Realizing the full potential of research translation requires enhancing the performance and participation of a broad range institutions of higher education. NSF’s new Technology Innovation Partnerships (TIP) division and the Accelerating Research Translation (ART) program offer an opportunity to respond to the societal needs for more sustainable and inclusive growth across regions, sectors, and individuals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This workshop identified current obstacles, potential improvement strategies, and metrics for success for the NSF Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships (TIP) Accelerating Research Translation (ART) program. Topics discussed included building capacity and infrastructure for translational research at US Institutions of Higher Education (IHEs) and enhancing IHE’s role in regional innovation ecosystems. The workshop brought together seventy-five different professional perspectives from academia, industry, government, and foundations.  Over a day and a half, his workshop had multiple breakout sessions with report-outs to the group and general discussion among participants. Participants were allocated to seven tables, each with a pre-appointed facilitator, designated note taker, and a rapporteur selected by the table participants. The breakout sessions among each table addressed the following topics using 4-6 discussion questions per topic: enhancing translational efficiency and effectiveness, engaging internal and external stakeholders, and creating a support platform. The primary workshop activities included a pre-workshop presentation and readings to acquaint people with the NSF TIP ART program and a post-workshop survey and summary documents. The summaries served to solicit feedback, affirm participant buy-in and support, and confirm that the workshop recommendations reflected the in-person discussions and addressed any lingering ideas or thoughts. Under Chatham House Rules this workshop provided actionable recommendations to NSF.  

 


Last Modified: 04/15/2024
Modified by: Maryann P Feldman
